About the good things that we can have
 If we close our eyes

The idea of “opening your eyes” is often used to describe “seeing behind the curtains” or ‘waking up’ to a higher state of consciousness where you can see things for how they really are.
He is saying that someone is trying to suppress humanity’s thinking by keeping them distracted with the promise of materialistic objects or “good things”

Alternatively, this could be interpreted as a couple ignoring their problems so that they can continue their relationship built on a ‘false reality" in which both partners are keeping themselves distracted with good times and pretending that their relationship is working.

I know your mind’s made up
 You’re gonna cause more misery
Everyone is wrong about everything all the time. If you aren’t constantly second-guessing yourself you will likely cause harm in the long run.

Although your mind’s opaque
 Try thinking more if just for your own sake

One of George Harrison’s first philosophical songs, an unusually harshly-worded warning about the perils of leaving bad deeds unrectified. The inspiration behind the song is unknown. In his 1980 autobiography, Harrison claimed not to remember its origins, although he made a self-deprecating reference to the likes of “Taxman” and “Piggies”:

“Think for Yourself” must be written about somebody from the sound of it – but all this time later I don’t quite recall who inspired that tune. Probably the government.
- George Harrison

Whereas a number of Harrison’s later songs were fileld with pseudo-cosmic wisdom, “Think for Yourself” is remarkable for its earthy sourness.
’Cause I won’t be there with you
George can’t stand by you and talk you through every decision. You must be able to think for yourself if you want to guarantee “correct” thoughts.
